text:
WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Kathleen M. Roth.
Address 514 10th St., Saskatoon, Sask.
Birthplace North Dakota, U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? Nov. 6, 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? East End, 30-32-74 W2
Where had you been living before that? North Dakota, U.S.A.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Five plus children
How far was it to your nearest store? Seven miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? As we brought three car loads of house, horse, cow, furniture & machinery, we brought a year supply of flour, 2 hundred weight of white sugar, and one hundred of brown sugar.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? We had 13 hundred weight of maple running flour
In what quantities did you buy it? 1.2 bgs. 150 weight
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 3.50
How much did you use graham flour? Just for Graham Bread
Whole wheat flour? 5 lbs. 10 cts. in 3 months
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? So. What year? 17.29
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 80 cts.
What other grain products did you use? Bran for brown bread
Cornmeal? Whole wheat? No
Farina? Yes
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes at times
How did you grind it? In simple coffee mill

Although our family was only five there were 45 bachelors within a radius of 5 miles so my mother never let anyone leave without a meal or cup of tea. We held open house for as long as she lived. She died 1948 at the age of 74.
I am writing to you from my home in London, where I have been living for several months now. The weather here is quite pleasant, with temperatures ranging from 15 to 20 degrees Celsius.

Yesterday, I attended a meeting at the local library, where we discussed the latest developments in technology. It was an interesting event, and I met some new people who seem very enthusiastic about the topic.

I am planning to visit my family next week, so I will be away for a few days. I hope you are doing well and enjoying your time here.

Please let me know if there is anything else you need help with. I am always here to assist you in any way possible.

Take care and stay safe.

[Signature]

[Date]
A wonderful hospital woman and had over one hundred friends who corresponded with her up in till she died Jan. 6, 1948.

She along with her husband in Bolton, Ont., was 19 and he was 21 when they lived at

Celebrate the 50th anniversary 1934 and also the 75th anniversary

On the 15th November 1948 together they both were an active interest in work affairs. They were mentally a-pressing very much a few days before their death. Each being in hospital only a day and a half. She was a hard worker and they suffered losses a great loss but were always able to go again.

Aug. 12th 1914. They lost a tug Barn 11 head of horses during

Cows, pigs, chickens, etc. The

Farm was situated with Rippling

at 12 mile north of Owen Sound at the time they knew it.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ........................................... 50 lbs.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ......................... $0.50
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...................................... Edwardsburg
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ....................................... 6 oz.
At what price? .................................................................................. $1.50
Mostly we liked Brown sugar syrup.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ......................... We brought our cows to Stanley Rapp.
Butter? ............................................................................................. Made our own.
Eggs? ............................................................................................. Had our own hens.
What was the price of butter? ............................................................ $2.00
Did you pack eggs for winter? ............................................................. Yes
Did you make butter? ........................................................................... Yes
Did you make cheese? ........................................................................... Yes
What kind of cheese? ........................................................................... Cottage, only
Killing cattle, cheese was what we used.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ........................................ Killed our own
Beef and Pork. Had 3 hundred of both before.
How did you get fresh meat? ............................................................... Kept Beef in Jake Chest.
That lasted all winter.
How often did you get fresh meat? ....................................................... We had Rats & wild game.
How did you preserve meat? ................................................................ Just by Salting.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ........................................ No, not till after 1915
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? ............................................................................... Yes
What kinds? ....................................................................................... Prairie chicken, Partridge, Plover, Quail, Some Geese.
For how long? .................................................................................... When they came close enough to skin.
What part did fish play in the family diet? .............................................. We could always obtain fresh fish from Long Lake District.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? .................................................... Fresh
Kinds? ............................................................................................. Pike, Pickerel, White fish.

In 1907 Andy Robinson who was from North Dakota sent my father two lots of frozen fish out of Long Lake with a friend who came to Joe Weber's for wood. They were lovely fish, some of them weighing 5-8 pounds when thawed. It was a treat.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Black tea at what price? $2.50 per lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Coffee Southern

Price? $4.00 per lb.

What other beverages were used? Coffee

7. VEGETABLES AND OTHER FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?

Could you get potatoes at the store?

If not, where from? From South Dakota

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1923-24

Carrots 1923-24

Onions 1923-24

Turnips 1923-24

Beets 1923-24

Exceptionally good turnips

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 5 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box

What weight? 10 lbs.

How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes

Could you tell me what was the price of prunes? $1.50 per lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apricots, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?

A friend sent us a box containing about 20 lbs. of dried apples as pickings for other fruit.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No

peas? No

corn? No

beans? No

Saskatoons? No

other foods? No

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1915

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1915

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1915

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? No

How much money do you figure to cost?

To what extent?

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes

We brought a barrel of vinegar with us from South Dakota when the keg was emptied by my mother who came from overseas. We added water, apple peelings, cores, and added water to them. We kept them for some time. Then strained the juice and added some brown sugar to the mixture in the keg. We had good vinegar in a short time. I think the original keg was 50 lbs. full.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal yeast Cake
Did you make yeast for your own use? No Using starter? No
Using hops? No Salt rising?
Did you buy baking powder? Yes Baking soda? Yes
Cream of tartar? Yes Did you make your own baking powder? Yes we used cream of tartar & soda in some bakers
| Item                        | Price |
|-----------------------------|-------|
| Soda Bicarbonate             | $1.45 |
| Cream of Tartar             | $1.60 |
| Brown Sugar                 | $3.60 |
| Salt                        | $1.50 |
| Table salt                  | $1.50 |
| Dried eggs                  | $1.00 |
| Dried corn                  | $1.00 |
| Vinegar                     | $1.25 |
| Raisins                     | $1.25 |
| Shells                      | $1.25 |
| Carrots                     | $1.25 |
| Cheese (Cheddar or other)   | $1.25 |
| Vanilla                     | $1.25 |

10. Baking

What type of yeast did you use? ____________
Did you make yeast for your own use? ____________
Using yeast? ____________
Salt rising? ____________
Did you buy baking powder? ____________
Baking soda? ____________
Other? ____________

Yes...Mrs. Haddad says she uses it.
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING FOR THE REST OF THE ITEMS:

| Item                  | Earliest Date It Appeared | Approximate Price at the Time |
|-----------------------|---------------------------|-------------------------------|
| Canned Salmon         | Very Little               |                               |
| Canned Carrots        |                           |                               |
| Other canned fish     |                           |                               |

As the apples were green in color, they were stored in the cellar.

Apples - Fresh
- 15 lbs. 10¢ each

Lettuce
- 15¢ each

Tomatoes - Fresh
- Canned 1 crate 24 tins

Bananas
- 16¢ each

Lemons
- 3 for 10¢

Oranges
- 60¢ each

Cornflakes
- Didn't have packaged cereal

Other prepared breakfast cereals - give names.

Pearl tapioca
- 10¢ each

Instant tapioca
- 10¢ each

Bagel
- Yes, small amounts by lb.

Dates
- Had dates for Xmas 1907

Walnuts
- 17¢ each

Icing sugar
- Made our own icing by boiling chocolate, sugar & milk.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout)
- Well water & very good water

How far was this water from your home?
- About 1/2 mile

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank)
- Pail

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

Still carrying to house by same method, at farm north of Walton. My brother farms the homestead & other land. Name Ted J. Henderson. Bachelor. (corn)
In the midst of our daily routine,
A moment of stillness we find.
The world around us fades away,
As thoughts of love fill our mind.

We stand in quiet contemplation,
Our hearts filled with tender emotion.
In this peaceful haven we find,
A moment of peace, pure and kind.

And though the years may pass by,
Our love remains ever the same.
For in this quiet corner of life,
We find our truest home.
As we found mucilagino by the
big water pool full on the upper
Grassia especially when it had
been burnt. My opinion was

we at all we could publish some
smoother made a camp
their dry salting greening two
in unique sugar a specie. Very good
in sugar.

We also used mucilagino
of Rancho Guadalupe and Best Hope
a Municipio lotan and San Lorenzo
for wood
the Puffy Ball Mucilagino
which grew in abundance there
but we sliced it or cut it back
the other plain variety & mucilagino
there were an elastic character
wild mucilagino, which even tended
along mountain side at low lands in
abundance we picked Jackson
berries in thick water pools.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Soap.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes.

What kind of laundry soap did the washerwoman use? Royal Lemon.

The water was fairly soft so we did not need a softener.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood, certainly.

Where did you get your fuel? From farmers who lived about 5 miles away.

Describe any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

My brother still gets wood & cuts in 2' lengths for cooking & heating. Kitchens they have used for heating living room & bedrooms, etc., since 1915 and for night firing in both the kitchen & ladies store. Up to the present summer, I have used only wood and coal, all stored in sunshine.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

How many of the neighbors?

By whom was your first cook stove made? Majestic Co., M-3-A.

That year was it purchased? 1906.

Price? $125.00.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homesteader)

Wooden.

For preparing food? (Skillets, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

Chopping board, ironstone, china, white ware.

When did you first see enamel ware? Bought some in Aug. 1910.

Aluminum? 1915.

I bought 40.00 worth. Covering 4 tea kettles and double boilers. Large kettle, large pan, pan, cookie sheet, sugar pan, coffee pot, all of which are still in use. I was married Sept. 15, 1915, and from that time on had helped with all dressings at the farm or any other large gathering.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

 Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

 All packages were in paper bags excepting flour & sugar which were in cotton bags from 10 lbs up to 100. The 100 lb bag had cotton & coarse brown gunny sack over top. Now they come in heavy Paper Bags.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer. This was dinner.

| Item                  | Quantity |
|-----------------------|----------|
| Hot cereal, rolled oats or corn meal, wheat grits or corn meal |          |
| Toast or Bread & Butter, coffee |          |
| If the men were going to work outside, bacon eggs for them. Morning? Never ate them for breakfast |

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

In Dec 25, 1906.

Had Turkey, apple salad, Christmas cake, plum pudding, our own make, mince pie.

A whole mail bag of mail to Mr. Creaman said who operated store at Creaman. No household, each one owns for themselves.

Sons: George J. Ed. Daughter: Kathleen, George Miller

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We had to live for about three months on frozen potatoes & frozen turkeys. We put them in cold water & peeled them while still frozen. Then cooked them in boiling water. They tasted as good as the ones which had not been frozen.

There was once or twice we were reduced to last sipper of flour but never entirely out. I baked bread for the bachelor sold in 2 large 2lb loafs for 25¢ each at first. Sold in 2 large 2lb loafs for 25¢ each at first. Then they bought us the flour & paid 25¢ per 100 lbs for me to make into bread. Made 300 loaves a week.
16. **SHARPENING AND GRINDING**

   Certain tools sharpened which you recall in the workshops and smithies.

   - **Poveshell Road** (not purchased). (Give it was here possible.)

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the workers of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate monthly rent or surplus.

18. What did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada approximating areas at that time.

19. How did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada approximating areas at that time.

**Plum pudding**, our own make, **mince pie**

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

You didn't have or couldn't buy the different kinds of fare in 1906 or 1907. No canned soups or precooked or storage in ice refrigerators. So food had to be used more quickly. Sometimes needed forethought to prevent spoiling.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

After 1915, I began to use Baker's Bread at Watson's. It was much cheaper than baking for a small family at the time. I less work. I had previously baked from 15 to 40 loaves a week so that was one reason. It was a change. We got very good bread then. We always did buy the odd luxury like flour or butter in winter if we felt we needed it.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

One year we picked 130 quarts of Saskatoons and we had over 30 quarts of wild strawberries. The same to raspberries. Some wild cranberry jam & jelly and of course added to it with crates of plums & peaches. In the early days our home was the gathering place on Sunday evening. We had a piano which I had played for years & my brother a violin. Some others had different kinds of instruments such as banjo, mandolin, auto harp & mouth organ & while much like a flute and beautifully played by Tom Conner.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the management of the family.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home-prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

22. Please add other details free from any preconceived notions of buying groceries.

In the early days we had our own garden. We grew vegetables and fruits. We also kept chickens and raised pigs. We used these products to make our own bread and preserves.

One year we picked 30 quarts of wild strawberries. The same year we also gathered 50 quarts of raspberries. Some wild edibles included jam, jelly, and of course, added to our diet. Especially in the fall and winter, we would gather berries and nuts.

We had a piano which I had played for years. A boy friend had a violin. Sometimes we would play different kinds of music together.

town. Robins
Now among the families of this
Early Day. My father tried the first
Republican Senate in 1907, and the
first anytime time to stand manual
Buck at East end of Kansas. He built
the first Road North & South from
his school to his house. He was my
father, born Ramblin, Hugh Marshall
my father's name. W. H. Marshall.
Dear Sir,

In reading over my notes it seems to me that you will understand we were not in the same circumstances as some of the pioneers. My father, after paying all the expenses of moving had $800 in the Bank & we brought a 500 prairies and the furniture of a large household 5 Bedrooms & the house all well furnished & carpeted except the kitchen Linen.

My Father was an excellent man with Meat, Butchering and curing his own. He could lay his hand to do most any kind of work Carpentry, Machinery Livestock etc. acted as vet, Veterinarian to those who had feet.
Dear Sir,

In reply to your notice, I desire to inform you that you will understand we were not in the same circumstances as some of the farmers. My family, after buying all the supplies necessary had $800 in the bank and the brought a 500 piano and the furniture to a large amount.

We have been living in a well furnished carpeted house.

My father was an excellent man with great building and during his own he could lay his hand to do many and tried to work carpentry, masonry, etc., acted as seat vellum, etc., to the very best of my knowledge.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
animals. He was born and raised till after they were married at Bolton, Ont., near Toronto. His grandfather came to Canada from Scotland in 1920. My mother's people came from Ireland the same year to the district known as Toronto now.

Some of the early settlers near us died from exposure to the cold or from lack of fuel or food, and loneliness helped to discourage quite a few. Stanley Lipp of Huron and Addison Shantz & E.B. Cressman at Wallroos are three of the pioneer men who were in the locality when we moved in.

Sincerely,
(Mrs.) Kathleen M. Rath
animals. He was born and raised in New York City. His parents came from Ireland in 1820. They moved to Canada in 1830.

Some of the early settlers near us died from exposure to the cold. Others found a friend and continued helped to discourage fruit a few.

Stanley Lynn & Company and additional stores at 2 B. Creaman at Warrens are three of the pioneer ones who were in the locality when we moved in.

Sincerely, Nathan M. Ruth (Mrs.)
